questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel "stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
76%


Eosinophils
1%


Lymphocytes
20%


Monocytes
3%


Platelet count
360,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
36 mm/hr


Serum



 Antinuclear antibodies

positive


Rheumatoid factor
negative


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic JIA can manifest with asymmetrical oligoarthritis, chronic anterior uveitis, and positive antinuclear antibodies. Although this condition typically occurs in patients with a history of psoriasis, arthritis may, in rare cases, precede the onset of skin lesions. However, in psoriatic JIA, small to medium-sized joints, in particular the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints, and/or the spine are typically affected. The involvement of large, weight-bearing joints in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

B) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious arthritis manifests with an acute onset of polyarthritis, which is often asymmetrical and migratory, and predominantly affects the weight-bearing joints. Sacroiliitis, insertional tendinopathy, dactylitis, and conjunctivitis may also occur. Although this patient presents with arthritis and ocular symptoms similar to conjunctivitis, the slow progression of her condition, absence of recent infection with a typical pathogen (e.g., shigella, yersinia), and presence of antinuclear antibodies make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Seronegative polyarticular JIA is characterized by the involvement of ≥ 5 joints within 6 months of disease onset. Typical manifestations include symmetrical arthritis of the interphalangeal joints, cervical spine, and temporomandibular joint as well as chronic anterior uveitis. While seronegative polyarticular JIA may also affect large joints and manifest with laboratory findings similar to those of this patient, predominant asymmetrical involvement of weight-bearing joints without concurrent arthritis of the smaller joints is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Enthesitis-related arthritis is a type of JIA that manifests with enthesitis and/or asymmetric, oligoarticular arthritis of the lower limbs. Acute anterior uveitis may also develop during the course of the disease. However, enthesitis-related arthritis is most commonly seen in boys aged 9–12 years old and has a strong association with HLA-B27, inflammatory bowel disease, and positive family history of ankylosing spondylitis. Furthermore, this patient does not have features suggestive of enthesitis (e.g., swelling of tendons and ligaments), and her history of chronic (rather than acute) anterior uveitis makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic JIA typically occurs in children 2–4 years of age and is characterized by asymmetric arthritis involving ≥ 1 joint; large joints such as the knee, ankles, and wrist are often affected. However, systemic JIA also manifests with episodes of fever with spikes that occur on at least three consecutive days, as well as further systemic symptoms (e.g., salmon-pink rash, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly/hepatomegaly, serositis). Chronic anterior uveitis and positive antinuclear antibodies are not typically seen in systemic JIA.

F) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA, which is the most common type of JIA and typically affects girls between 2–4 years, is defined as arthritis that involves ≤ 4 joints within 6 months of disease onset. Typical manifestations include asymmetric swelling, early morning stiffness, and limited and/or painful movement of large weight-bearing joints (e.g., knees, ankles). Chronic anterior uveitis is seen in approx. 25% of oligoarticular JIA cases and may manifest with recurrent episodes of ocular pain, redness, and photosensitivity. Laboratory studies typically show elevated ESR, positive antinuclear antibodies, and a negative rheumatoid factor (see “Classification of JIA” table).

Patients with mild to moderate disease activity can be treated with a combination of NSAIDs and intraarticular glucocorticoids, while patients with severe disease may require treatment with a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)
questions.hint: Asymmetric arthritis that lasts > 6 weeks and involves ≤ 4 joints in combination with chronic bilateral anterior uveitis and positive antinuclear antibodies is typical of a specific type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

questions.text:
A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of pain in her left wrist and right knee for 4 months. She has not had any trauma to the knee or any previous problems with her joints. She attends daycare. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee and left wrist shows mild swelling, tenderness, and warmth; range of motion is slightly decreased. No other joints are affected. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9,000/mm3



Platelet count
200,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
50 mm/h


Serum



 Antinuclear antibodies

positive


 Rheumatoid factor
negative


This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atlantoaxial subluxation is a potential complication of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA is most common in female individuals and typically manifests with arthritis and elevated ESR. However, RA does not affect children. This patient's presentation indicates oligoarticular JIA; cervical spine involvement and, thus, atlantoaxial subluxation, are rare in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of sacroiliac joints is seen in seronegative spondyloarthropathies, which can manifest with asymmetrical oligoarthritis, elevated ESR, and negative rheumatoid factor. However, seronegative spondyloarthropathies typically affect male individuals between 20 and 40 years of age and are not associated with positive ANA titers. This patient's presentation indicates oligoarticular JIA; involvement of the sacroiliac joints is not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The development of rheumatoid nodules on valvular structures is a potential complication of rheumatoid arthritis and seropositive polyarticular JIA, both of which manifest with a positive rheumatoid factor. This patient's presentation indicates oligoarticular JIA, which is not associated with valvular lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Nephritis is a potential complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This condition most commonly affects female individuals and can manifest with arthritis, positive ANA titers, and elevated ESR. However, children < 5 years are rarely affected. Moreover, SLE is characterized by symmetrical involvement of both small and large joints as well as further signs and symptoms such as fever, fatigue, rashes, and cytopenia. Oligoarticular JIA is not associated with nephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysm is a potential complication of Kawasaki disease, which can manifest with oligoarthritis and an elevated ESR. However, almost all patients develop fever, and 4 out of 5 additional features (conjunctival injection, erythema of the palms and soles, rash, cervical lymphadenopathy, strawberry tongue) must be present to establish a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

F) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA is associated with chronic anterior uveitis (often bilateral) in ∼ 25% of cases. Regular ophthalmologic screening is recommended in patients with JIA to identify and treat asymptomatic anterior uveitis early to help prevent further complications, such as cataracts, iris synechiae, glaucoma, and blindness.

Factors that increase the risk of developing anterior uveitis include a positive ANA titer and diagnosis of oligoarticular JIA at age < 6 years.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)
questions.hint: Arthritis that involves ≤ 4 joints within 6 months of disease onset, in combination with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titers in a 3-year-old girl, raises concern for oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 3-day history of swelling of her right knee. The father says he has occasionally noticed her limping in the morning for the past 2 months. She has not had any recent trauma. Six months ago, she had a swollen left ankle and an episode of uveitis that resolved spontaneously. She has no history of major medical illness and receives no medications. Family history is noncontributory. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. The right knee is swollen, warm, and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 45 mm/h. Additional laboratory studies are most likely to show an increase of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) is found in patients with seropositive polyarticular JIA. This type of JIA most commonly affects girls and is associated with an elevated ESR. However, seropositive polyarticular JIA is characterized by the symmetrical involvement of ≥ 5 joints (typically small joints such as interphalangeal joints) within 6 months of disease onset, which is not the case here. This patient's presentation with asymmetrical arthritis of two large joints (i.e., knee, ankle) indicates oligoarticular JIA, which is not associated with an increased RF. In addition, seropositive polyarticular JIA most commonly manifests in patients 9–12 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This condition is most common in female patients and typically manifests with arthritis, morning stiffness, and an elevated ESR. However, toddlers are rarely affected. Moreover, SLE is characterized by symmetrical involvement of both small and large joints as well as further signs and symptoms such as fever, fatigue, rashes, and cytopenia, none of which are seen here. Oligoarticular JIA is not associated with increased anti-dsDNA antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs) are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). This condition is most common in female patients and typically manifests with arthritis, morning stiffness, and an elevated ESR, which are seen here. However, RA does not affect children. This patient's presentation indicates oligoarticular JIA, which is rarely associated with increased ACPAs.

D) CORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in approx. 70% of patients with oligoarticular JIA, the most common type of JIA. This condition most commonly manifests in girls 2–4 years of age. Oligoarticular JIA manifests with asymmetrical arthritis of ≤ 4 large, weight-bearing joints (e.g., knees, ankles) within 6 months of disease onset. The affected joints are often stiff in the morning, as seen here, with mobility improving with activity throughout the day. Chronic anterior uveitis is a serious complication of oligoarticular JIA that can lead to permanent vision loss and is associated with the presence of ANAs (see “Classification of JIA” table).
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCAs) are found in 40–80% of patients with Crohn disease (CD). Arthritis is a common extraintestinal symptom of CD, present in approx. ⅓ of affected children, and may precede the gastrointestinal symptoms. Asymmetric involvement of large joints, as seen here, is typical. Moreover, CD is associated with an elevated ESR and uveitis. Though there are cases of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in toddlers (i.e., very early-onset IBD), CD is rare at that age. Moreover, further signs and symptoms would be expected in a child with CD, such as poor weight gain, constitutional symptoms, and anemia. This patient's presentation indicates oligoarticular JIA, which is not associated with increased ASCAs.
questions.hint: Signs of arthritis (e.g., painful swelling, warmth) of two joints and an episode of uveitis within a period of 6 months, in combination with an elevated ESR in a 2-year-old girl suggest oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because of a 6-week history of pain in both knees. She has not had any recent trauma. She also reports having progressive pain in her hands for the last 3 months. The pain is worst in the morning and improves approximately 1 hour after she gets up. Four months ago, she was diagnosed with gastroenteritis, which resolved spontaneously within 4 days. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 50th percentile for weight and height. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows warmth, tenderness, and swelling of the knees, ankles, and second and third metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally; range of motion of the affected joints is limited by pain. There are nontender, firm, subcutaneous swellings on the extensor surfaces of both forearms. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 35 mm/h. A serum rheumatoid factor assay is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the knees with synovial fluid analysis is indicated in patients with suspected septic arthritis, which can manifest with joint pain and restricted range of motion. However, septic arthritis involves one rather than multiple joints, has an acute rather than insidious onset, and typically manifests with fever. In addition, positive RF and rheumatoid nodules are not characteristic of septic arthritis. This patient has seropositive polyarticular JIA, for which arthrocentesis is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Seropositive polyarticular JIA is a rare type of JIA associated with an aggressive disease course and a high risk of progressive joint destruction. Prompt management is essential for preserving joint functionality in affected individuals and typically includes a combination of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin) provide symptomatic relief of joint pain and stiffness, while DMARDs (e.g., methotrexate) help prevent joint destruction. Patients who fail to respond to DMARD therapy may require treatment with biologic agents (e.g., etanercept, adalimumab).

While JIA is typically idiopathic, viral or bacterial infections (e.g., gastroenteritis) may also trigger the disease.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)

C) INCORRECT:

An anti-dsDNA antibody assay can be used for the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which manifests with symmetrical polyarthritis and elevated ESR. However, patients with SLE typically also present with other characteristic symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and a malar rash. In addition, rheumatoid nodules and positive RF are not characteristic of SLE. This patient has seropositive polyarticular JIA, which is not associated with an increase in anti-dsDNA antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool cultures can be used in the workup of reactive arthritis, which commonly occurs following an episode of bacterial infection (e.g., gastroenteritis). However, reactive arthritis typically has an acute (1–4 weeks after infection) rather than insidious onset (4 months after infection), and manifests with asymmetric migratory oligoarthritis, rather than symmetric polyarthritis. In addition, positive RF and rheumatoid nodules are not characteristic of reactive arthritis. This patient has seropositive polyarticular JIA, which requires a different intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) may be considered for the treatment of severe systemic JIA, which can manifest with polyarthritis and elevated ESR. However, systemic JIA typically manifests with constitutional symptoms such as fever, salmon-pink rash, and serositis, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, positive RF and rheumatoid nodules are not characteristic of systemic JIA. This patient has seropositive polyarticular JIA, for which a short course of systemic glucocorticoids may be considered as second-line therapy if mobility is significantly impaired. Nevertheless, systemic glucocorticoids are generally avoided in children because of their numerous side effects, which include growth impairment and osteoporosis.
questions.hint: This 12-year-old girl with symmetrical arthritis of ≥ 5 joints that developed within 6 months of disease onset, rheumatoid nodules, elevated ESR, and positive rheumatoid factor has seropositive polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to clinic reporting bilateral temporal headache, jaw pain, and reduced chewing ability for the past 2 months. She also reports a childhood history of episodic joint pain and swelling involving her right knee and left ankle. She often limped as a toddler and was given ibuprofen for “growing pains” at a young age. She denies any history of upper-extremity pain, unusual fevers or rashes, or eye problems.
Her vital signs today are within normal limits. Head and neck examination reveals micrognathia and dental malocclusion. The patient has crepitus and palpable pain over the right temporomandibular joint when opening and closing her mouth. She has a leg-length discrepancy, with the right leg 1.5 cm longer than the left. There are no knee effusions, and she has full range of motion in the knees. The left ankle has some restricted range of motion on flexion and extension as compared to the right ankle. The rest of the examination, including the remainder of the musculoskeletal examination, is normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7800
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.0
12.0–16.0


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
10
1–25


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
0.5
0.08–3.10


A basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. Testing for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody is negative. An antinuclear antibody test is positive at a dilution of 1:320 (reference range, negative at 1:40 dilution) with a diffuse pattern.
Which one of the following diagnoses most likely explains this patient’s jaw pain?

choices.text: Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, now in adulthood
Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, now in adulthood

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis can be associated with TMJ arthritis but, by definition, this diagnosis is made in patients age 16 years or older at the time of first symptoms. This patient’s history is most consistent with a childhood presentation of inflammatory arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic TMJ dysfunction manifests with facial pain, ear pain, and jaw dysfunction. This patient’s history of childhood inflammatory arthritis makes idiopathic TMJ dysfunction unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Although elevated ANA levels are often seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), this patient does not have any symptoms of SLE, such as constitutional symptoms, rashes, or anemia and leukopenia. The elevated ANA level in this case is a feature of oligoarticular JIA.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic JIA is a syndrome characterized by daily high fevers and transient rashes during childhood, neither of which are reported in this case. Systemic JIA does not have the long-term association with TMJ dysfunction, micrognathia, and uveitis that the oligoarticular subset has.

E) CORRECT:

Although this patient is not reported to have been diagnosed with arthritis during childhood, her history is consistent with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Oligoarticular JIA is defined as synovitis of up to four large joints, typically the knees and ankles but sometimes the wrists and elbows. It affects girls more frequently than boys and has a peak incidence at 2 to 4 years of age. Approximately 75% of patients with oligoarticular JIA develop temporomandibular joint (TMJ) arthritis, as in this case. TMJ arthritis typically manifests with pain and crepitus but can lead to micrognathia as a result of damage to the mandibular growth plate during childhood. Children with oligoarticular JIA should be routinely monitored for TMJ arthritis because the symptoms often go unreported. Active synovitis of the TMJ should be treated aggressively to avoid complications of micrognathia and malocclusion. Treatment options include glucocorticoid injections and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate or biologic agents. In this case, the patient does not necessarily have active synovitis, and the described structural abnormalities are mostly postinflammatory and not likely to respond to antirheumatic drugs.

Children with all forms of inflammatory arthritis can develop limb-length discrepancies, especially if there is asymmetric disease activity in a knee. Age of disease activity determines the type of length discrepancy. If the inflammatory arthritis is active before puberty, the affected side often grows longer than the unaffected side because of increased blood flow to the metaphysis of the long bones. If the inflammatory arthritis is active during adolescence, the affected side is often shorter than the unaffected side because of premature growth arrest secondary to inflammation. Sometimes, a limb-length discrepancy in a young adult is the only physical-examination clue to the history of inflammatory arthritis. In this case, the patient also has evidence of restricted range of motion at the tibiotalar joint on the historically affected left ankle.

Children with oligoarticular JIA should also be routinely monitored for the development of autoimmune uveitis, which is another well-recognized complication of JIA with potentially long-term consequences into adulthood. Patients with oligoarticular JIA often have a modestly elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) level, as in this case. This elevation often persists into adulthood but is not necessarily indicative of an additional autoimmune disorder.

Key learning point: Patients with a childhood history of oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis and micrognathia should be routinely screened for temporomandibular joint arthritis.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl reports a 3-month history of joint pain and swelling in her knees, ankles, wrists, and proximal interphalangeal joints. During this time, she has also had 1.4 kg of weight loss, jaw pain, difficulty chewing, and morning stiffness of 2 to 3 hours. She has not had any rash, hair loss, oral ulcers, fever, general malaise, abdominal pain, diarrhea, eye pain, or eye redness. She has no family history of inflammatory disorders.
Her vital signs are normal, and she appears well and comfortable. She has swelling, diminished range of motion, and tenderness in both knees, her right ankle, her left wrist, and her third to fifth proximal interphalangeal joints on both hands. She has limited jaw opening and tenderness at the temporomandibular joint on the left. The rest of her physical examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal comprehensive metabolic panel; a normal complete blood count except for a hematocrit of 30% (reference range, 35–45); an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 55 mm per hour (0–20); a C-reactive protein level of 34 mg/liter (0–5), and negative results for antinuclear antibody, antistreptolysin O, anti-DNase antibody, and Lyme serology.
Radiographs of the knees reveal moderate-size bilateral joint effusions and several erosions on the right knee.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA is the most prevalent subtype of JIA and involves fewer than five joints. It tends to affect the large joints, but not the hip. Many patients test positive for antinuclear antibody (ANA).

B) CORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is a complex group of disorders that does not have a clearly defined cause. It is the most common rheumatic disease of childhood, with a prevalence of about 1 in 1000 children. However, there continues to be some debate about classification of this group of disorders. The diagnosis requires the persistence of arthritis for more than 6 weeks in a child ≤16 years of age who has no other identified cause of arthritis.

There are seven subtypes of JIA (figure), and the most likely subtype in this patient is polyarticular JIA. Polyarticular JIA involves at least five joints, tends to be symmetric, and is more common in girls than boys. Polyarticular JIA can be positive or negative for rheumatoid factor (RF) and anticitrullinated protein antibodies (ACPA). It is useful to check for RF and ACPA status because seropositive patients are more likely to follow a chronic course typical of adult-onset rheumatoid arthritis. Eye involvement in polyarticular JIA is not as common as in ANA-positive oligoarticular JIA, but all patients with JIA should have regular ophthalmologic evaluations.

See “Classification of juvenile idiopathic arthritis” table.

Key learning point: Arthritis involving five or more joints for at least 6 weeks in a patient younger than 16 years of age is most compatible with a diagnosis of polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Joint involvement is common in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), but other organ systems are also typically involved, as evident in the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings. A negative ANA test is usually sufficient to rule out SLE.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic JIA has systemic manifestations, such as fever, evanescent rash, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia can mimic oligoarticular JIA and frequently manifests with migratory arthritis of a small number of joints. This patient’s weight loss and anemia certainly raise concern for this condition, but the large number of joints involved, the solitary anemia, and the lack of peripheral blasts make this condition less likely.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to clinic reporting bilateral temporal headache, jaw pain, and reduced chewing ability for the past 2 months. She also reports a history of episodic joint pain and swelling involving her right knee and left ankle during elementary school. She often limped as a toddler and was given ibuprofen for “growing pains” at a young age. She denies any history of upper-extremity pain, unusual fevers or rashes, or eye problems.
Her vital signs today are within normal limits. Head and neck examination reveals micrognathia and dental malocclusion. The patient has crepitus and palpable pain over the right temporomandibular joint when opening and closing her mouth. She has a leg-length discrepancy, with the right leg 1.5 cm longer than the left. There are no knee effusions, and she has full range of motion in the knees. The left ankle has some restricted range of motion on flexion and extension as compared to the right ankle. The rest of the examination, including the remainder of the musculoskeletal examination, is normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8800
4500–13,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.0
12.0–16.0


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
9
0–10


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
4.8
0–5.0


A basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. Testing for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody is negative. An antinuclear antibody test is positive at a dilution of 1:320 (reference range, negative at 1:40 dilution) with a diffuse pattern.
Which one of the following diagnoses most likely explains this patient’s jaw pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis can be associated with TMJ arthritis but, by definition, this diagnosis is made in patients age 16 years or older at the time of first symptoms. This patient’s history is most consistent with a childhood presentation of inflammatory arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic TMJ dysfunction manifests with facial pain, ear pain, and jaw dysfunction. This patient’s history of childhood inflammatory arthritis makes idiopathic TMJ dysfunction unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Oligoarticular JIA is defined as synovitis of up to four large joints, typically the knees and ankles but sometimes the wrists and elbows. It affects girls more frequently than boys and has a peak incidence at 2 to 4 years of age.

Approximately 75% of patients with oligoarticular JIA develop temporomandibular joint (TMJ) arthritis, as in this case. TMJ arthritis typically manifests with pain and crepitus but can lead to micrognathia as a result of damage to the mandibular growth plate during childhood. Children with oligoarticular JIA should be routinely monitored for TMJ arthritis because the symptoms often go unreported. Active synovitis of the TMJ should be treated aggressively to avoid complications of micrognathia and malocclusion. Treatment options include glucocorticoid injections and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate or biologic agents. In this particular patient, a TMJ MRI should be obtained to assess whether the TMJ symptoms are related to active arthritis or prior damage, as this would influence treatment.

Sometimes, a limb-length discrepancy in a young adult is the only physical-examination clue to the history of inflammatory arthritis; the discrepancy may be due to overgrowth or to growth-plate arrest, depending on the age of onset and type of arthritis.

Children with oligoarticular JIA should also be routinely monitored for the development of autoimmune uveitis, which is another well-recognized complication of JIA with potentially long-term consequences into adulthood. Patients with oligoarticular JIA often have a modestly elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) level, as in this case. This elevation often persists into adulthood but is not necessarily indicative of an additional autoimmune disorder.

Key learning point: Patients with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis and micrognathia should be routinely screened for temporomandibular joint arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although elevated ANA levels are often seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), this patient does not have any symptoms of SLE, such as constitutional symptoms, rashes, or anemia and leukopenia. The elevated ANA level in this case is a feature of oligoarticular JIA.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic JIA is a syndrome characterized by daily high fevers and transient rashes during childhood, neither of which are reported in this case. Systemic JIA does not have the long-term association with TMJ dysfunction, micrognathia, and uveitis that the oligoarticular subset has.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with 4 months of worsening hip, ankle, and low back pain. The back pain is worst when he wakes up and after a long day of sitting in class, but it improves with soccer practice after school. A previous course of physical therapy did not improve his symptoms, nor has 3 months of naproxen 500 mg twice daily. He has no other significant medical history and does not take any daily medications. He reports no unintentional weight loss, abdominal pain, bloody stools, or changes in bowel habits.
On examination, he appears well. Joint examination shows no warmth, tenderness to palpation, or limited range of motion. He has tenderness over the Achilles tendon insertions, over the insertional sites of both greater trochanters, and over both sacroiliac joints.
Laboratory evaluation is notable for a normal complete blood count, a C-reactive protein level of 16 mg/liter (reference range, 0–5), an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 38 mm/hr (0–10), and HLA-B27 positivity.
Which one of the following tests is the best next step to determine the appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the ankles can be helpful in assessing for the presence and severity of ankle arthritis when there is clinical concern. However, this patient’s lack of ankle swelling, warmth, pain with palpation, or limitation in motion makes active arthritis at this site unlikely, and thus advanced imaging is not indicated at this time. His pain over the Achilles tendon insertions is consistent with enthesitis, which is not typically associated with changes on ankle MRI at presentation, especially in children.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has enthesitis-related arthritis (ERA), a subset of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Enthesitis is inflammation of the entheses, the sites where tendons or ligaments insert onto the bone. Common sites of enthesitis include the Achilles tendon, insertion of the plantar fascia, 12 o’clock and 6 o’clock patellar poles, tibial tuberosity, and greater trochanter. The diagnosis of enthesitis is usually made clinically based on a history of inflammatory-type pain (i.e., pain that is worse in the morning and with inactivity and that is unresponsive to physical therapy) and an examination finding of tenderness over insertional sites.

ERA is classified as a spondyloarthropathy, a class of inflammatory arthropathies that also includes ankylosing spondylitis, a more progressive form of arthritis that typically affects adults.

ERA in children <16 years of age is defined as arthritis plus enthesitis OR either condition in combination with at least one of the following features:

• Sacroiliac (SI) tenderness or inflammatory lumbosacral pain
• HLA-B27 positivity
• Onset of arthritis in a boy >6 years old
• Acute (symptomatic) anterior uveitis
• First-degree relative with ERA, sacroiliitis associated with inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis, or acute anterior uveitis

This patient meets criteria for ERA given his age, enthesitis, inflammatory lumbosacral pain, SI tenderness, and HLA-B27 positivity. Although the diagnosis of ERA can be made without further evaluation, imaging can help determine the severity of his inflammatory disease and guide treatment. His low back pain is concerning for sacroiliitis (inflammation of the SI joints) and did not improve with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Confirming the presence of sacroiliitis is important before proceeding to the next line of treatment. In children and adolescents, SI changes are rarely seen on plain radiographs, so MRI of the pelvis is the gold standard for diagnosing sacroiliitis. The presence of active sacroiliitis should lead to an escalation in therapy to tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors if NSAIDs are not effective and a child is still having daily pain in the sacroiliac region. There are no data that conventional disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs are effective for spinal disease in spondyloarthritis.

Key learning point: For a patient with inflammatory lumbosacral pain or sacroiliac tenderness on examination, the best next step to determine the severity of inflammatory disease and choose an appropriate treatment regimen is MRI of the pelvis to evaluate for sacroiliitis.

C) INCORRECT:

In children and adolescents, SI changes are rarely seen on plain radiographs, so MRI of the pelvis is the gold standard for diagnosing sacroiliitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unlike in other subclasses of JIA, the antinuclear antibody test (ANA) is characteristically negative in patients with ERA, as are rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Although ANA positivity can increase one’s risk of uveitis, it would not change diagnosis or ERA management for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the hips is often used to confirm hip arthritis, as effusions are difficult to appreciate on examination. However, this patient does not demonstrate any signs of active hip arthritis (e.g., limited range of motion or pain along the inguinal canal with movement). His pain over the greater trochanters is most consistent with enthesitis. Furthermore, sacroiliitis cannot be diagnosed by ultrasound.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 4-year-old girl presents with right-knee swelling and a 3-month history of morning stiffness. Her parents say that she limps every morning for an hour or so but then resumes her regular activities with no difficulty. She has not reported any pain, and they only recently noticed the swelling.
There is no associated fever, no recent infection or trauma, and no known exposure to Lyme disease. The girl has no family history of arthritis or psoriasis.
Her right knee is very swollen and warm, with a mild flexion contracture. The physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
What is the most likely ocular complication to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) — defined as arthritis lasting more than 6 weeks with no known cause in a child younger than 16 years of age — is the most common rheumatologic disease of childhood.

Oligoarticular JIA (the most likely diagnosis in this case) involves fewer than five joints and predominantly affects the large joints, most often the knees, ankles, wrists, and elbows. It is the most common form of JIA, constituting 50% of cases, and is typically seen in young girls. Affected patients do not typically have much pain, and parents often notice local swelling, a limp, diminished activity, and/or morning stiffness.

Children with oligoarticular JIA should be routinely monitored for the development of autoimmune uveitis, which is a well-recognized complication of JIA with potentially long-term consequences into adulthood. Uveitis occurs in approximately 25% to 30% of children with oligoarticular JIA and is the most common ocular complication in this population. Often a child is completely asymptomatic (or unable to articulate symptoms), and the finding is present only on slit-lamp examination. Conjunctival injection is frequently absent.

Key learning point: The most common ocular complication in children with chronic monoarthritis is uveitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis is much more common in adults with other autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, vasculitis, lupus, and some infectious diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Scleritis (a very severe, sight-threatening inflammation of the sclera) rarely occurs in children but is associated with systemic autoimmunity in 50% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis is characterized by inflammation of the eyelids with eye irritation, but it is not specifically associated with juvenile arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cataracts may occur in chronic, untreated uveitis, but this is less likely than uveitis alone. Cataracts may also arise from chronic glucocorticoid treatment.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl presents with 3 months of knee and wrist pain. Her pain is at its worst when she wakes up and after sitting in class all day. She feels best when she is walking or participating in dance. Recently, she has had difficulty opening her water bottle after dance practice and turning doorknobs.
She is otherwise healthy with no significant medical history. Her mother has mild psoriasis, and her sister has ulcerative colitis. The patient is on no medications, and a review of systems is negative.
Her physical examination is notable for swelling of the left knee, right wrist, and right third and fourth distal interphalangeal joints as well as swelling and tenderness of her entire left third toe.
Which one of the following additional physical examination findings will confirm this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Thick reddish-brown longitudinal lines along the nail bed
Pinpoint depressions scattered on multiple fingernails

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cuticular overgrowth and nail-fold capillary dilation are nail abnormalities seen in juvenile dermatomyositis. Nail-fold capillary dilation can be seen in other forms of autoimmune disease including scleroderma, lupus, and some vasculitides.

B) INCORRECT:

Nail-fold capillary dilation can be seen in other forms of autoimmune disease including scleroderma, lupus, and some vasculitides. Cuticular overgrowth and nail-fold capillary dilation are nail abnormalities seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.

C) INCORRECT:

Thick reddish-brown to black longitudinal lines along the nail bed describes a splinter hemorrhage. When these lines appear proximally, they can be characteristic of endocarditis and a variety of vasculitic and rheumatologic disorders. Although splinter hemorrhages can occasionally be seen in patients with psoriasis, they are uncommon in this setting and are usually seen distal in the nail bed.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has psoriatic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (psJIA), which is characterized by arthritis in combination with either psoriasis or at least two of the following features:

• Dactylitis (swelling of a digit beyond the borders of the joint; typically uniform and sometimes referred to as a sausage-like digit; can be asymptomatic or erythematous and painful)
• Nail pitting (pinpoint depressions scattered on multiple fingernails) or onycholysis (painless detachment of the nail bed from the finger, usually beginning at the tip of the finger)
• Family history of psoriasis in a first-degree relative

Psoriasis occurs in only 40% to 60% of cases of psJIA and may be subtle, with lesions hidden on the scalp, behind the ears, or in the umbilicus, making a thorough skin examination necessary. The lesions can occur in different forms but most commonly appear as erythematous plaques with overlying scale.

Key learning point: A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis requires arthritis in combination with either psoriasis or at least two of the following features: dactylitis, nail pitting or onycholysis, or a first-degree relative with psoriasis.
Image Description:

Fingernails of the right hand show widespread pitting (resulting from parakeratosis within the nail plate) and onycholysis (i.e., distal separation of the nail plate).

These are common features of psoriatic nails.

E) INCORRECT:

Transverse leukonychia describes horizontal white lines on the nail and is commonly seen in the absence of pathology. Certain chronic medical conditions are associated with transverse leukonychia, but psoriatic arthritis is not one of them.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl reports that her right fifth finger has been puffy for the past week. Ibuprofen seemed to provide some comfort, but the appearance of the finger did not change. Topical mupirocin has not helped.
The child is otherwise healthy. She has been eating and drinking normally. She has had no fever, abdominal pain, weight loss, recent viral illnesses, or physical trauma.
On examination, she appears well. There is uniform swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation of her right fifth finger as well as swelling and limited range of motion of her right wrist. A thin, erythematous, 1-cm plaque is noted behind her left ear. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which one of the following conditions may be a complication of this patient’s underlying disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis and chronic renal insufficiency can occur in patients with psJIA, particularly if they have concurrent autoimmune conditions (such as autoimmune hepatitis) or medication toxicities (e.g., methotrexate, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs). However, neither condition would be expected as a complication of psJIA itself.

B) INCORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of dactylitis includes sarcoidosis. Pediatric patients with sarcoidosis, particularly older children and adolescents, can present with lung infiltrates and hilar lymphadenopathy. However, the presence of skin manifestations consistent with early psoriasis in this patient makes sarcoidosis less likely than psJIA. Although uveitis can also be seen in sarcoidosis, most patients with sarcoidosis develop ocular symptoms such as eye redness or pain, in contrast to the silent uveitis seen in psJIA.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with dactylitis, which is characterized by swelling, tenderness, and often erythema of an entire digit or segment of a digit. Her examination also shows a thin, erythematous plaque behind her ear, which is suspicious for psoriasis. Taken together, the triad of dactylitis, arthritis, and psoriasis is consistent with psoriatic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (psJIA). Other features of psJIA include nail pitting (small depressions in the surface of a nail), onycholysis (detachment of a nail from the nail bed), and enthesitis (inflammation of the sites in which tendons or ligaments insert onto bone). Some patients report a family history of psoriasis.

Patients with psJIA have an increased risk for uveitis, an inflammatory eye disease. Because the uveitis in psJIA tends to be clinically silent (without pain, photophobia, or conjunctival injection), routine ophthalmologic screenings with slit-lamp examinations are strongly recommended, starting at the time of the psJIA diagnosis. The frequency of screenings depends on specific patient factors but generally ranges from 3 to 12 months. Risk factors for uveitis include young age (≤6 years old), female sex, certain subtypes of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (including psJIA), and antinuclear antibody positivity. Overall, 10% to 15% of psJIA patients develop uveitis, which can lead to cataracts, glaucoma, and ultimately permanent vision loss if left untreated.

Patients with psJIA have an increased risk for inflammatory bowel disease, so clinicians should remain vigilant for signs of colitis, such as abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and weight loss.

Key learning point: All patients with a new diagnosis of psoriatic juvenile idiopathic arthritis should be evaluated for uveitis.

D) INCORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of dactylitis includes sickle cell disease. In patients with sickle cell disease, vaso-occlusive crises can manifest clinically as dactylitis. However, the presence of skin manifestations consistent with early psoriasis in this patient makes sickle cell disease less likely than psJIA.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis and chronic renal insufficiency can occur in patients with psJIA, particularly if they have concurrent autoimmune conditions (such as autoimmune hepatitis) or medication toxicities (e.g., methotrexate, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs). However, neither condition would be expected as a complication of psJIA itself.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel "stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. A serum antinuclear antibody assay is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enthesitis-related arthritis is a type of JIA that manifests with enthesitis and/or asymmetric, oligoarticular arthritis of the lower limbs. Acute anterior uveitis may also develop during the course of the disease. However, enthesitis-related arthritis is most commonly seen in boys aged 9–12 years old and has a strong association with HLA-B27, inflammatory bowel disease, and positive family history of ankylosing spondylitis. Furthermore, this patient does not have features suggestive of enthesitis (e.g., swelling of tendons and ligaments), and her history of chronic (rather than acute) anterior uveitis makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

B) INCORRECT:

Seronegative polyarticular JIA is characterized by the involvement of ≥ 5 joints within 6 months of disease onset. Typical manifestations include symmetrical arthritis of the interphalangeal joints, cervical spine, and temporomandibular joint as well as chronic anterior uveitis. While seronegative polyarticular JIA may also affect large joints and manifest with laboratory findings similar to those of this patient, predominant asymmetrical involvement of weight-bearing joints without concurrent arthritis of the smaller joints is unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA, which is the most common type of JIA and typically affects girls between 2–4 years, is defined as arthritis that involves ≤ 4 joints within 6 months of disease onset. Typical manifestations include asymmetric swelling, early morning stiffness, and limited and/or painful movement of large weight-bearing joints (e.g., knees, ankles). Chronic anterior uveitis is seen in approx. 25% of oligoarticular JIA cases and may manifest with recurrent episodes of ocular pain, redness, and photosensitivity. Laboratory studies typically show elevated ESR, positive antinuclear antibodies, and a negative rheumatoid factor (see “Classification of JIA” table).

Patients with mild to moderate disease activity can be treated with a combination of NSAIDs and intraarticular glucocorticoids, while patients with severe disease may require treatment with a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic JIA typically occurs in children 2–4 years of age and is characterized by asymmetric arthritis involving ≥ 1 joint; large joints such as the knee, ankles, and wrist are often affected. However, systemic JIA also manifests with episodes of fever with spikes that occur on at least three consecutive days, as well as further systemic symptoms (e.g., salmon-pink rash, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly/hepatomegaly, serositis). Chronic anterior uveitis and positive antinuclear antibodies are not typically seen in systemic JIA.

E) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic JIA can manifest with asymmetrical oligoarthritis, chronic anterior uveitis, and positive antinuclear antibodies. Although this condition typically occurs in patients with a history of psoriasis, arthritis may, in rare cases, precede the onset of skin lesions. However, in psoriatic JIA, small to medium-sized joints, in particular the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints, and/or the spine are typically affected. The involvement of large, weight-bearing joints in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.
questions.hint: Asymmetric arthritis that lasts > 6 weeks and involves ≤ 4 joints in combination with chronic bilateral anterior uveitis and positive antinuclear antibodies is typical of a specific type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old girl presents with right-knee swelling and a 3-month history of morning stiffness. Her parents say that she limps every morning for an hour or so but then resumes her regular activities with no difficulty. She has not reported any pain, and they only recently noticed the swelling. There is no associated fever, no recent infection or trauma, and no known exposure to Lyme disease. The girl has no family history of arthritis or psoriasis. Her right knee is very swollen and warm, with a mild flexion contracture. The physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most likely ocular complication to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA is the most common form of JIA, constituting 50% of cases, and is typically seen in young girls. Affected patients do not typically have much pain, and parents often notice local swelling, a limp, diminished activity, and/or morning stiffness.

Children with oligoarticular JIA should be routinely monitored for the development of autoimmune uveitis, which is a well-recognized complication of JIA with potentially long-term consequences into adulthood. Uveitis occurs in approximately 25% to 30% of children with oligoarticular JIA and is the most common ocular complication in this population. Often a child is completely asymptomatic (or unable to articulate symptoms), and the finding is present only on slit-lamp examination. Conjunctival injection is frequently absent.

Key learning point: The most common ocular complication in children with chronic monoarthritis is uveitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis is much more common in adults with other autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, vasculitis, lupus, and some infectious diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Scleritis (a very severe, sight-threatening inflammation of the sclera) rarely occurs in children but is associated with systemic autoimmunity in 50% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis is characterized by inflammation of the eyelids with eye irritation, but it is not specifically associated with juvenile arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cataracts may occur in chronic, untreated uveitis, but this is less likely than uveitis alone. Cataracts may also arise from chronic glucocorticoid treatment.
questions.hint: Oligoarticular JIA, the most likely diagnosis in this case, involves fewer than five joints and predominantly affects the large joints, most often the knees, ankles, wrists, and elbows.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with a 3-month history of swollen, painful wrists and knees. She experiences morning stiffness for about an hour that gradually improves through the day. She has had intermittent episodes of similar symptoms over the past year. There is no fever or rash. Physical examination reveals tenderness and decreased range of motion in the affected joints. Laboratory tests show mild anemia, normal white blood cell count, and slightly elevated inflammatory markers.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis typically presents acutely with a single, severely affected joint, high fever, and elevated white blood cell count. The prolonged course, polyarticular involvement, and morning stiffness easing with activity suggest an inflammatory rather than infectious process. The absence of fever and normal white blood cell count further reduce the likelihood of septic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever follows group A streptococcal pharyngitis and presents with migratory polyarthritis, not chronic joint inflammation. The multi-month history of joint swelling and morning stiffness is inconsistent with acute rheumatic fever's brief migratory episodes. Additionally, systemic features like fever or carditis are absent.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can present with arthritis, anemia, and elevated inflammatory markers. However, it typically affects adolescent females and involves systemic features like rashes, photosensitivity, or renal issues, which are absent here. The pattern of morning stiffness improving with activity suggests chronic inflammatory arthritis rather than SLE's multisystem involvement.

D) CORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis manifests in patients under 16 years with arthritis lasting at least six weeks. The chronic joint pain and swelling, particularly in the wrists and knees, align with this condition. Prolonged morning stiffness improving with activity is a hallmark of inflammatory joint disease. Laboratory findings of mild anemia and slightly elevated inflammatory markers indicate a chronic inflammatory process rather than an acute or infectious cause.

Key learning point: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis is characterized by chronic joint inflammation, morning stiffness, and recurrent episodes of joint pain and swelling in children.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents with mild morning stiffness and intermittent swelling of her right knee for three months. Examination reveals a warm joint with limited end-range motion but no significant pain at rest. She has no fever or rash and remains active. ANA testing is positive, and other laboratory findings are within normal limits. She has never experienced eye pain or redness.
Which of the following is the most appropriate screening measure to detect a known extra-articular complication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum rheumatoid factor testing is used to classify arthritis subtypes but does not correlate with the risk of uveitis in juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Detecting uveitis, a key extra-articular complication, requires regular ophthalmologic examinations, not serologic markers like rheumatoid factor.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiograms evaluate cardiac structure and function, relevant in conditions with cardiac involvement, such as Kawasaki disease. Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis is primarily associated with ocular complications, not cardiac issues, making regular slit-lamp examinations the appropriate screening measure.

C) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, especially in antinuclear antibody (ANA)-positive patients, carries a significant risk for chronic anterior uveitis, which is often asymptomatic. Slit-lamp examination is the most effective method for detecting early inflammatory changes in the uveal tract. Early detection is crucial to prevent complications such as cataracts, glaucoma, and vision loss. Regular ophthalmologic screening with slit-lamp evaluations enables timely intervention and management, reducing the risk of long-term ocular damage.

Key learning point: Oligoarthritis JIA is characterized by the involvement of 4 or fewer joints within the first 6 months of disease, often with a positive ANA, and is the most common form of JIA in young girls.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)

D) INCORRECT:

Routine chest radiographs assess lung pathology, such as interstitial lung disease, which is not characteristic of oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis. This condition is more commonly associated with ocular complications, necessitating ophthalmologic examinations rather than pulmonary imaging.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 4-year-old girl who presents with right knee swelling and a 3-month history of morning stiffness. Her parents report that she limps every morning for about an hour, after which she resumes her regular activities without difficulty. She has not complained of pain, and the swelling was only recently noticed. There is no fever, recent infection, trauma, or known exposure to Lyme disease. There is no family history of arthritis or psoriasis. On examination, her right knee is very swollen and warm, with a mild flexion contracture. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most likely ocular complication to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scleritis (a very severe, sight-threatening inflammation of the sclera) rarely occurs in children but is associated with systemic autoimmunity in 50% of cases.

B) CORRECT:

Oligoarticular JIA is the most common form of JIA, constituting 50% of cases, and is typically seen in young girls. Affected patients do not typically have much pain, and parents often notice local swelling, a limp, diminished activity, and/or morning stiffness.

Children with oligoarticular JIA should be routinely monitored for the development of autoimmune uveitis, which is a well-recognized complication of JIA with potentially long-term consequences into adulthood. Uveitis occurs in approximately 25% to 30% of children with oligoarticular JIA and is the most common ocular complication in this population. Often a child is completely asymptomatic (or unable to articulate symptoms), and the finding is present only on slit-lamp examination. Conjunctival injection is frequently absent.

Key learning point: The most common ocular complication in children with chronic monoarthritis is uveitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cataracts may occur in chronic, untreated uveitis, but this is less likely than uveitis alone. Cataracts may also arise from chronic glucocorticoid treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis is characterized by inflammation of the eyelids with eye irritation, but it is not specifically associated with juvenile arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis is much more common in adults with other autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, vasculitis, lupus, and some infectious diseases.
questions.hint: Oligoarticular JIA, the most likely diagnosis in this case, involves fewer than five joints and predominantly affects the large joints, most often the knees, ankles, wrists, and elbows.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents who are concerned about persistent swelling in his left wrist and right ankle for the past 10 weeks. His parents report that he is particularly stiff in the mornings and has difficulty getting dressed, but seems to improve as the day progresses. He has a past medical history of eczema. He has no fever or systemic symptoms. Physical examination reveals swelling of the left wrist and right ankle with mild warmth. Laboratory results show normal white blood cell count and C-reactive protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis typically affects large joints (especially the knee) and occurs in endemic areas with tick exposure history. The bilateral small and large joint involvement over 10 weeks without appropriate exposure history makes Lyme arthritis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection, usually affects joints in the lower limbs, and is accompanied by extra-articular signs such as conjunctivitis and urethritis. The absence of a preceding illness, and extra-articlualr features, makes reactive arthritis less likely. Additionally, reactive arthritis rarely causes such prolonged morning stiffness.

C) INCORRECT:

Juvenile dermatomyositis is characterized by progressive symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin findings such as heliotrope rash and Gottron papules on extensor surfaces. This patient presents with joint swelling rather than muscle weakness, and no skin changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is typically self-limiting and resolves within days to weeks. A 10-week duration with persistent morning stiffness extending beyond the expected timeframe for transient synovitis makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets the criteria for juvenile idiopathic arthritis: arthritis in a child under 16 years of age persisting for more than 6 weeks (10 weeks in this case). The characteristic morning stiffness that improves throughout the day is a classic feature of JIA. The asymmetric involvement of wrist and ankle with chronic duration strongly suggests oligoarticular JIA.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of worsening knee pain and swelling for the past 3 months. She has not had any recent trauma. The pain is worse in the morning and improves throughout the day. She also reports having progressive pain in her hands for the last 5 months. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows warmth, tenderness, and swelling of the knees, ankles, and second and third metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally; range of motion of the affected joints is limited by pain. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 35 mm/h. A serum rheumatoid factor assay is positive. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Which of the following synovial fluid findings are expected in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals are found in pseudogout, which typically affects older adults and involves large joints such as the knee or wrist. Pseudogout is rare in children and does not manifest with chronic, symmetrical, polyarticular arthritis or positive rheumatoid factor.

B) CORRECT:

Synovial fluid analysis in inflammatory noninfectious arthritis (e.g., JIA) typically shows an elevated leukocyte count of 2,000–50,000/mm3, with a predominance of neutrophils. Septic arthritis usually shows a leukocyte count > 50,000/mm3 with a high proportion of neutrophils. A low leukocyte count with minimal neutrophil presence is characteristic of noninflammatory joint conditions.

See “Interpretation of synovial fluid analysis” table.

C) INCORRECT:

A leukocyte count > 50,000/mm3 with a high proportion of neutrophils is characteristic of septic arthritis, which manifests acutely with a single swollen joint, high fever, and systemic toxicity. This patient presents with subacute, symmetrical, and polyarticular joint involvement without pronounced systemic symptoms, making septic arthritis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

A low leukocyte count with minimal neutrophil presence is characteristic of noninflammatory joint conditions such as osteoarthritis and traumatic effusions. These conditions do not manifest with marked morning stiffness, symmetrical polyarthritis, or systemic inflammation.

E) INCORRECT:

Monosodium urate crystals are diagnostic of gout, which is rare in children and manifests with acute monoarticular arthritis, usually affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint. This patient is 9 years of age and has chronic symptoms involving multiple joints, which are not consistent with gout.
questions.hint: This 9-year-old patient presents with symmetrical arthritis of ≥ 5 joints that developed within 6 months of disease onset. These findings in combination with elevated ESR and positive rheumatoid factor indicate seropositive polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
